title: Will there be a lethal confrontation in the South or East China Sea between the military forces, militia, or law enforcement personnel of China and another country before 1 January 2020?
preds: Updating to my forecast, which I made in March. I'm adjusting the probability downwards from 12% because of the passing of time. A quick news search didn't reveal much new information. Tensions occasionally increase (https://www.express.co.uk/news/world/1207963/south-china-sea-china-us-warships-vietnam-beijing-spt), but Trump reportedly have not paid much attention to this particular topic (https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2019/dec/07/america-losing-battle-for-pacific-power-solomon-islands-china). Basically, I find it unlikely that the US government will significantly change their attitude or approach during these final weeks of december.

The base rate on the 50-year baseline, multiplied by the the time left in the question, has dropped to 0.477%, which rounds down to 0%.   The 10-, 20-, 30-, 40-, and 60-year baselines already dropped below the 0.5% mark ( https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/927963 ).

Number of occurrences of events of the specified type (military/militia/law enforcement on both sides, leading to a death) over the last . . . 10 years: Zero times.
20 years: One time.
30 years: One time.
40 years: Two times.
50 years: Three times.
60 years: Three times. Accordingly, chance of the specified event happening in the remaining 34 days this year if we take the number of times in those periods as the rate: 10 years: 0/10*34/365 = 0.000%, rounds to 0%
20 years: 1/20*34/365 = 0.466%, rounds to 0%.
30 years: 1/30*34/365 = 0.311%, rounds to 0%.
40 years: 2/40*34/365 = 0.466%, rounds to 0%.
50 years: 3/50*34/365 = 0.559%, rounds to 1%.
60 years: 3/60*34/365 = 0.466%, rounds to 0%. A 70-year baseline is harder to calculate, since it's hard to say how many times it happened in the first two Taiwan Straits crises. The PRC took full power in October 1949, so a baseline longer than 70 years seems foolish to me, but would dramatically inflate the number of confrontations as we start adding in World War II. I've been using the 30-year baseline, because that covers pretty much the whole modern era of international relations (post-Cold War) and Chinese internal politics (post-Tienanmen).

Currently, President Xi mainly struggled about four issues - serious economic downturn, trade war against US, Hong Kong protests, internal conflicts within CCP.  Taiwan: Although conquering Taiwan is an important goal of CCP, now it seems too difficult to achieve by either non-military means or military means. Sending army to Taiwan will trigger US and western countries' vigorous  response and aggravate the above four main issues and even lead to instant collapse of CCP. I put 0.5% on this scenario.  Hong Kong: As a Hongkonger, I think CCP by now is still reluctant about sending People's Liberation Army to crack down Hong Kong's protest, though the probability of this happening is larger than sending army to Taiwan. Hong Kong's issue is much more urgent than Taiwan's. I put 2% on this scenario. Other cases: For example, China has conflict with countries around South China sea. I put 0.5% on these possibilities. 0.5%+2%+0.5%=3%

The probability of this event is small, which makes calibration difficult. If we look at the history of clashes in ECS/SCS there is a pair of events with victims (battle of the parecels in 1974, a second skirmish between Chinese and Vietnamese vessels in 1988), giving a bases probability of 1% for what remains of the year (see, e.g. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/903572 ). But the number of clashes has increased, and the incident with the Philippino vessel was a close call. In 2017-2018 we heard about 18 unsafe encounters, which gives us another handle to compute a contribution for this probability: in the next three months, we could expect 2 other unsafe encounters, and we could give them a 1% probability of deriving into a lethal confrontation (there have been already 18, so it is sensible to assume less than 1/18 probability of the encounter ending in a fight, and a much lesser change of ending in deaths). Assuming that the extra 2% does not correlate with the previous, we end up with a 3%.

The South/East China Sea borders Japan, Philippines, Vietnam, Taiwan, and the PRC. Therefore, it must be assumed that any lethal confrontations will have at least one of these parties involved. The Japanese, US and China have been in dispute over the Senkaku islands since 1990. Given the military strength of the Philippines and Vietnam, I am doubtful that they will be involved in any way. Although tensions are high between China and the US due to the trade war, I don't believe it is a matter which can be resolved through military force. Plus, any conflict between two major powers such as China and the US would have too great of an impact on the rest of the world, so I doubt anything that drastic would occur while Trump is campaigning for his re-election.  It might be plausible that China would want to show their military might given the civil unrest in Hong Kong, and given that China has been militarizing the disputed islands in the Southern sea, it may be plausible for some degree of force to be exercised in that avenue. However, given the sensitive political climate, with international backlash over alleged Chinese influence in Hong Kong, I find it unlikely that any such action will be taken.

The Philippines may invoke its mutual defense treaty with the United States if it finds the sinking of a Philippine fishing boat this month was the result of an armed attack by the Chinese, a spokesman for Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte said at press briefing Monday. Spokesman Salvador Panelo said the Philippines will invoke the treaty “if it is the right thing to do with that agreement,” according to a translated transcript of the briefing. The treaty calls for the U.S. to support the Philippines if it’s attacked by another country, he said. The Philippines filed a diplomatic protest last week after Filipino fishermen said a Chinese fishing vessel intentionally rammed their boat, the FB Gimver, anchored in Reed Bank on June 9 and left the 22 crewmembers for dead. Forbes reported yesterday that a high official in the Chinese government vowed in a statement that China is prepared to defend every “island and rock” that belongs to China. It is China's understanding, and wish, to control the entirety if the South China Sea, which has led to a number of disputes with a number of other South China Sea bordering states, such as Malaysia, The Philippines, Vietnam and Indonesia. According to Forbes, China will fail to control the South China Sea, as it lacks the resources and capabilities to successfully seize the sea, therefore the grand strategy is doomed to end badly (https://www.forbes.com/sites/panosmourdoukoutas/2019/06/08/china-must-either-trim-its-south-china-sea-sails-or-face-disaster/#210e38362975).  China's major issue in the South China Sea is that it is all alone. It is one player against all the other, including the navies of US, Japan, France, the UK, and Australia. These navies seek to enforce the freedom of navigation in the vast trade waterway Forbes point out (https://www.forbes.com/sites/panosmourdoukoutas/2019/06/08/china-must-either-trim-its-south-china-sea-sails-or-face-disaster/#5fe77d422975). Yannis Tsinas, a retired Washington diplomat and Greek naval officer, points out that even though China has made major improvements to its naval and military capabilities, it still does not match those of the US and its allies.  If one assumes that China is aware of this, as one must in this case, the natural response is also to assume that China would want to be careful in the South China Sea, in order to avoid a lethal confrontation, seeing as the consequences would be grave. However, their rhetorics tell a different story, having at several occasions pointed out that they are willing to do whatever to gain control of the sea, indicating that they do not fear a lethal confrontation and the consequences. In regards to the historical data on the matter, incidents have occurred, but non that fit the criteria listed in the question.           The East China Sea has also been prone to conflict, especially between China and Japan. In June 2018 a communication line was established between the two states in order to avert accidental clashes in the air and at sea, putting aside their difference in the East China Sea, in order to avoid accidents  (https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy-defence/article/2149835/china-japan-hotline-launched-avoid-sea-air-clashes). With that being said, tensions still remain high as both Japan and China have increased their military presence in and around the sea (https://nationalinterest.org/blog/buzz/china-vs-japan-east-china-sea-showdown-back-61492). With this being said I land on a likelihood of 30%, solely based on China's aggressive rhetorics indicating that they will continue their aggressive strategy in both seas, resulting in the other neighbouring states having to adopt similar strategies in order to match China's. It is my understanding that lethal confrontations are more likely to occur in hostile and aggressive environments, which I feel is an accurate description of the current environment in both seas. With that being said, I also believe that none of the states surrounding the seas wishes to see a lethal confrontation happen, meaning that they will avoid it as much as possible. Hence why my percentage is not set any higher.

In 2012 China called to become a maritime power, that is capable of safeguarding its maritime rights and interests (https://chinapower.csis.org/maritime-forces-destabilizing-asia/). Since then, China has engaged in building up its fleet and capacity, including the coast guard, in modernity and size. This is shown also in increased government spending on such matters. In late 2018 the Chinese President called for increasing capacities even further and to concentrate preparations for fighting a war (https://qz.com/1440601/chinese-military-command-monitoring-taiwan-south-china-sea-ordered-war-ready/). Specifically in the South China Sea the ongoing conflict about the nine-dash line, where China claims major parts of territory in the South China Sea, is a region of heightened concern. In the past there have been a couple of clashes, however, as can be found on the China Power website, past clashes have not led to fatalities yet, even though close. The last incident was in March 2019 where a Vietnamese vessel sank because a Chinese vessel was deploying a water canon on them (https://chinapower.csis.org/maritime-forces-destabilizing-asia/). However, this would also not fit the criteria listed by GJO, as it was a Vietnamese fishing vessel and not a military force, militia or law enforcement. Those concrete incidents have not happened - yet. Overall though, as the time frame is set quite a fair bit into the future still as it covers seven months, and one cannot predict which international relations may unravel in that time, with 12% a possibility of a lethal confrontation is still given. 

With regards to the East Chinese Sea, Japan as well as China have increased their capabilities as their territorial contest over the Senkakou/Diayou islands continue (https://thediplomat.com/2018/08/diaoyu-islands-dispute-a-chinese-perspective/). However, last year the two counries introduced a crisis hotline to avoid any accidental air or sea clashes (https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy-defence/article/2149835/china-japan-hotline-launched-avoid-sea-air-clashes), and with that are establishing enhanced trust among the two countries. Furthermore, considering the joint defence treaty between the US and Japan, which also covers the territory of the Senkakou/Diayou islands, if a lethal confrontation were to happen with a fatality on the Japanese side cause by China, China might have to face also retaliative action by the US, which is not in their favour (https://www.cfr.org/interactive/global-conflict-tracker/conflict/tensions-east-china-sea).

Note: As I read the questions, incidents that would be considered apply to this case would have to occur between official representatives of the Chine military or law enforcement and a foreign actor (civilians or officials). Hence, any lethal confrontations involving a foreign state and Chinese civilians would not apply in this situation.  Firstly, I attempt to construct a (crude) base-rate by looking closer at past confrontations in the South China sea. As the focus is on lethal confrontations, I am not too concerned about the definition a confrontation, but more so on the outcome (i.e. did the interaction result in deaths). Using the https://chinapower.csis.org/maritime-forces-destabilizing-asia/ count, I account for the number of incidents in the South China Sea. I include all incidents that involve Chinese vessels, but I indicate whether these are civilian or government vessel (in incidents where both occur, I make no distinction). Lastly, I note if the incidents involving China had lethal outcomes.  South China Sea 
2019: 2 (1 civilian) (4) incident involving China, 0 fatalities 
2018: 2 (2) incidents involving China, 0 fatalities 
2017: 3 (6) (1 civilian) incidents involving China, 0 fatalities 
2016: 12 (1 unidentifiable, 3 civilian) (15) incidents involving China, 0 fatalities 
2015: 8 (10) (3 unidentifiable, 1 ‘armed guards’)  incidents involving China, 0 fatalities 
2014: 7 (7) incidents involving China, 0 fatalities 
2013: 3 (4) (1 unidentifiable) incidents involving China, 0 fatalities 
2012: 3(3), incidents involving China, 1 week-long, 0 fatalities 
2011: 6 (6) (1 civilian)  incidents involving China, 0 fatalities. 
2010: 2 (2) incidents involving China, 0 fatalities. 
In total, there has been 59 incidents in the South China sea in the past 9 years and 48 of these have involved Chinese vessels, i.e. app. 81% of the confrontations. Out of these, 32 have been identified as official Chinese naval or coast guard vessels, i.e. 54 %. (Though there is a significant likelihood that the unidentified vessels were also official vessels). 
So, while there has been a significant amount of confrontations in the South China sea and Chinese vessels have been involved in a majority of them, with identified government vessels being involved in just above half of them, none of the incidents involving China have had lethal outcomes!  East China Sea 
I have been unable to found similar data on confrontations in the East China Sea, but the number of Chinese government vessels is increasing in both the contiguous zone and the territorial waters around the Senkaku/Diaoyu islands. Between 2009 and August of 2012, the number of Chinese government vessels venturing into these waters, where significantly lower. Though, the ones that were present did cause confrontations, and in 2010 it came to a full-blown diplomatic dispute between the two countries.   The number of Chinese vessel rapidly increased in the summer of 2012 in response to the Japanese Government acquiring some of the aforementioned island. The ships present have increasingly been armed and in 2016 it did came to another confrontation, however, this one did not escalate to the same extent (https://chinapower.csis.org/maritime-forces-destabilizing-asia/). Generally, major conflicts regarding the East China Sea have been avoided since 2013 (https://amti.csis.org/flashpoint-east-china-sea-potential-shocks/). 
Despite confrontations and tensions in the East China Sea, it seems there have been no lethal confrontations involving the Chinese  government vessels! 
Geopolitical tensions  The South and East China Seas have long been very contested international waters with overlapping territorial claims between China and Taiwan and China and Japan. In 2012, the Chinese government declared their intention of becoming a Maritime force and extent its military focus beyond land to the sea.  In the East China Sea, the fear is that the increasing the aggression of the Chinese presence will eventually lead to new confrontations. Especially the area around the Senkaku/Diaoyu islands is a source of tension, as the Chinese government does not recognize the Japanese claim. This has meant an escalation in patrols and flyovers from both sides. As the Chinese coast guard far and the costal guards ships have doubled in numbers since 2010 (https://chinapower.csis.org/maritime-forces-destabilizing-asia/) and thereby far outweighs the Japanese, and therefore, already is straining it capabilities, fears are that future incidents around the island will be escalate faster and, potentially, be more violent in nature. This concerns extends to the American forces in the area (https://amti.csis.org/flashpoint-east-china-sea-potential-shocks/).  In the South China Sea, the territorial disputes also involve Malaysia, Brunei, Vietnam, and the Philippines. They have contested China’s claims to vast areas in of the Sea and the rich oil and gas reserves, as well at the fishing stocks. The Chinese commitments to extending becoming a maritime super nation is mirrored in their military have been steadily rapidly increasing in the past years compared to other involved countries. The Chinese claim to the waters have been challenged in Permanent Court of Arbitration (PCA) in The Hague, but China does not recognize the court’s authority (https://dnnsociety.org/2016/07/15/south-china-sea-in-data/). The US’ also have vested interests in the region; both to limit Chinese domination and secure free trade routes. Their presence in the area have been a source of provocation for China on more than one occasion. 
The overlapping territorial claims, the increased military presence and the accompanying massive military spending (by especially China) shows that the East and South China Seas are indeed tense areas at the moment, where conflicts could readily spark and escalate quickly. Simultanously, data from the past 9 years show that while maritime incidents have been plentiful and Chinese vessels have been involved in majority of them, they have not had lethal outcomes. Hence, I find the chance of conflict or diplomatic disputes very likely, but the likelihood of a lethal outcome involving a Chinese government vessel within the next 6.5 months, I ascribe only a 12% likelihood.

The US Navy has been conducting so-called freedom of navigation operations near Chinese-controlled islands and reefs since 2015, to challenge what Washington calls Beijing’s “excessive claims in the waterway.” Four such operations were carried out under former president Barack Obama and there have been 11 so far under President Donald Trump.  These numbers were addressed this week as U.S. Navy operations chief John Richardson spoke at the IMDEX maritime security conference in Singapore May 15, 2019.  
•	He stated operations get more attention in the media and also have, sometimes from China, than they warrant.
•	He conducted analysis and stated with confidence that the US Navy’s level of operations has been consistent over the decades, adding the US hasn’t done anything increasingly provocative or anything else. Source: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-southchinasea/u-s-says-chinas-focus-on-its-south-china-sea-operations-unwarranted-idUSKCN1SL0MK?utm_source=applenews During the Obama era, such operations had more strategic significance so there was management from the higher level,” said Hu Bo, co-author of the report and director of the Centre for Maritime Strategy Studies at Peking University.  The Chinese navy could become less tolerant of US activities in the South China Sea. “As our capability grows, we are likely to take more actions to counter provocations,” he said. This hasn’t been a trivial or hypothetical question since at least April 2001, when a Chinese fighter jet hotdogging near a U.S. Navy EP-3 surveillance plane slammed into the American aircraft, kindling a diplomatic crisis between the Chinese Communist Party leadership and the newly installed administration of President George W. Bush. Tensions rose in September of 2018 when the USS Decatur was challenged by the Chinese destroyer Lanzhou during an operation near Gaven Reef, one of China’s artificial islands, and a collision was narrowly avoided.  The Chinese Luyang destroyer issued the stern verbal signal to the USS Decatur before sailing within 45 yards of the vessel. Source: Incident trackers from 2016 indicate rising trends of conflict-related incidents: https://chinaus-icas.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/10/SCS-Tracker-HCJ-2016-Draft.jpg https://chinaus-icas.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/10/SCS-Tracker-2017-new.jpg https://chinaus-icas.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/10/SCS-Tracker-HCJ-2018-Dec.jpg On diplomatic matters: Nov 20, 2018, Xi Jinping visits the Philippines - the first visit by a Chinese President in 13 years. Sources assert the likeliest collision scenario would involve a U.S. Navy warship and a Chinese fishing boat or China Coast Guard cutter.  Beijing uses fishing craft crewed by maritime militiamen and backed by cutters as the vanguard of its strategy in the South China Sea and the East China Sea. It floods the zone with them to the tune of thousands of fishing craft. Trawlers ply their trade in expanses where China asserts sovereign rights to natural resources. China Coast Guard white hulls dash to the rescue if a rival navy or coast guard challenges the fishing fleet’s presence. •	This is the paramilitary fleet that harassed the U.S. survey ship Impeccable in 2009 and has faced off against Philippine and Vietnamese maritime forces. There hasn’t been a collision yet (with US vessels)—quite—but there have been close calls.  Should non-military ships block the path of an American warship and a crash ensue, the optics—photos of a hulking destroyer mowing down a civilian vessel—would favor Chinese efforts to brand the U.S. Navy as overbearing, blundering, or both. The truth would take a backseat to message- which bring us to: China’s Three Warfare principle as a war by other means.  •	Psychological Warfare seeks to influence and/or disrupt an opponent’s decision-making capability, to create doubts, foment anti-leadership sentiments, to deceive opponents and to attempt to diminish the will to fight among opponents. It employs diplomatic pressure, rumor, false narratives and harassment to express displeasure, assert hegemony and convey threats.  China’s economy is utilized to particular effect. 
•	Media Warfare (also known as public opinion warfare) is a constant, ongoing activity aimed at long-term influence of perceptions and attitudes.  It leverages all instruments that inform and influence public opinion including films, television programs, books, the internet, and the global media network (particularly Xinhua and CCTV) and is undertaken nationally by the PLA, locally by the People’s Armed Police and is directed against domestic populations in target countries.  Media warfare aims to: preserve friendly morale; generate public support at home and abroad; weaken an enemy’s will to fight and alter an enemy’s situational assessment. It is used to gain ‘dominance over the venue for implementing psychological and legal warfare’.  
•	Legal Warfare (or ‘lawfare’) exploits the legal system to achieve political or commercial objectives. It has a prominent role in the warfare trilogy. Lawfare has a range of applications. They range from conjuring law to inform claims to territory and resources, to employing bogus maps to ‘justify’ claims. In a distorted application of domestic law.  China also uses UNCLOS provisions and other legal conventions for unintended purposes.

Per the parameters of this challenge- “a lethal confrontation is one that results in one fatality for the military forces, militia, or law enforcement of either side.”
China’s Three Warfare approach will likely continue as the predominant means of addressing conflict, but chances for collateral damage remains possible, specifically in the context of China’s paramilitary antagonist fleets and CG Cutters in an accidental or purposeful collision.

For national security, but more importantly to ensure control of the vast maritime trade routes. This forecast will briefly explain the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS) as it represents the fundament for territorial claims and resulting rights. The potential for lethal confrontations for both seas will be assessed individually and “summed up” later on to result in an overall forecast. After providing a brief summary of the issues concerning territorial claims the analysis will go on to assess if there were lethal confrontations (from 2010 onwards) already and how many clashes there have been between maritime vessels (China vs. X) to determine the actual conflict trend. This will be complemented by (briefly) examining the degree of militarization (in form of military spending) within the region and the diplomatic relations between opposing claimants in order to estimate the potential for future confrontations. It’s worth to mention that the time frame for this forecast is fairly limited.  The UNCLOS enables states to file for an expansion of their Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ), among other things. An EEZ guarantees a state the exclusive rights to use the resources, as well as provides further jurisdictional sovereignty, within its area. These expansions are often based on remote islands or other features. However, not all maritime features qualify for a rightful expansion (a core issue regarding the South China Sea). Regardless of court rulings countries in East Asia or South East Asia continue their expansion politics using the provision under the UNCLOS.  SOUTH CHINA SEA (SCS) 
The SCS is an example of how states use the UNCLOS to expand their jurisdiction through territorial claims. Especially the archipelagos of the Paracel Islands, Scarborough Shoal and Spratly Islands are used to justify territorial claims which in some cases comprise almost the whole of the SCS. Often the maritime features, which are used to back up these expansions claims, do not qualify under the UNCLOS as “natural islands” with ill-founded territorial claims as a result. Nonetheless, these maritime (artificial) features are used by littoral countries to increase their military presence, hence, consolidating their de facto control of the sea. Claimants who use this tactic are the Peoples Republic of China (PRC), the Republic of China (Taiwan), Vietnam and the Philippines (Malaysia and Brunei filed for claims but refrain from occupying maritime features). The claims of the PRC and Taiwan are identical as both states regard themselves as the only legitimate successor of the former Chinese Qing Empire. There are 3 main reasons why the SCS is lucrative for such expansions claims: 1) One of the most important international shipping routes transit through the SCS; 2) The fishing stock of the SCS are vital for the populations surrounding the sea and; 3) There are energy resources beneath the sea surface and analysts estimate that the actual amount of natural gas/oil might be higher than expected. Unfortunately, the mentioned claims overlap each other (Vietnam & PRC/Taiwan claims are almost identical) which causes increased tensions between states and an overall increased tension within the region. Additionally, the US pursue so-called Freedom of Navigation Operations (FONOPS) which aim to contest these claims and associated exclusive rights. The motivation lies within the US interest to defend the areas of international waters in order to maintain its military mobility and its ability to guarantee unobstructed passage for commercial vessels. All the mentioned aspects are drivers of the conflict and contribute to tensions and their development within the region.   Indeed, in 2015 and 2017 death incidents occurred in the SCS. However, none of them involved the PRC. These incidents might indicate a higher level of aggression in the region after all. The amount and intensity of confrontations between a PRC vessel(s) and other vessel(s) are distributed as follows:  YEAR | total amount | # of incidents with shots involved (guns and other) | # of incidents with ramming of ships involved | long time events occurred | events with more than 30 vessels occurred (# of vessels)  2010 | 2 | none | none | none | no
2011 | 6 | 1 | none | none | yes (30+) 
2012 | 3 | 1 | none | 1 | no

2015 | 14 | none | 7 | none | no
2016 | 13 | 3 | 7 | none | no
2017 | 3 | 2 | none | none | no
2018 | 3 | none | 1 | none | no In 2011 and in 2014 the conflict escalated up to a point which resulted in mass gatherings of ships. The peak of total amounts of incidents was in 2015 with 14 and closely followed by 2016 with 13 total incidents. 2016 could be called the most intense year with 3 incidents of fired shots and 7 ramming manoeuvres. 2017 and 2018, with only 3 total incidents each, represent a sharp decline in comparison to the years before. While the former year involved two incidents of fired shots, the latter only contains 1 event with ramming manoeuvres and, hence, could be called the calmest year since 2010. As a result, the current conflict trend can be assessed to be fairly low.   The militarization will be assessed by comparing the total military expenditure, as well as the expenditure as a share of gross domestic product (in constant 2017 US$; in m.) in the years 2010 (% of GDP) | 2012| 2014 | 2016 | 2018. The Philippines’ and Vietnam’s total expenditures increased from 2010 to 2018, however, the ratio regarding ‘share of GDP’ remained (more or less) steady. The PRC’s total expenditure increased by roughly 100 Billion US$ from 2010 to 2018 which equals an increase of 173%. Nonetheless, the military expenditure remained (more or less) the same with regards to the GDP at 1,9%. It is worth to mention that the PRC’s Navy (PLAN) focused on smaller vessels to increase the overall number of Navy vessels. The USA spend in 2018 almost 634 Billion US$ for military expenditures which equals 3,2%. Also, the USA cut their military budget since 2010 in total and relative terms. The data about military expenditure regarding littoral states (who occupy maritime features) of the SCS implies that there is no arms race due to lack of sharp raises of military budgets. It could be expected that littoral states would increase their military spending significantly if they expect that a major confrontation will occur. Nevertheless, the rise of the total budget bears the possibility for an increased conflict potential itself. Another factor which increases the potential of confrontation is the raised expenditure for coast guard vessels (or other maritime authorities’ vessels). Most encounters in the SCS and ECS involve such vessels rather than military ships. Indeed, the spending and the tonnage for such vessels increased from 2010 to 2016 for the PRC, Vietnam and the Philippines (no data available for Taiwan). The PRC almost doubled its actual tonnage from 2010 to 2016. Nevertheless, the spending for the coast guard only grew moderately. One result could be an increase of confrontations as these ships are used to “attack” the opponent indirectly. However, the actual trend of incidents is declining despite the increased tonnage which puts this aspect into perspective.  The PRC and Taiwan maintain a hostile relationship towards each other based on their common history. Both states see themselves as the rightful successor of the former Qing empire. The PRC repeatedly express their opinion that Taiwan is still a part of continental China and refuses to acknowledge Taiwan’s independence. However, the USA is supporting Taiwan, therefore, it seems unlikely that the PRC would act too aggressive towards Taiwan and Taiwanese vessels. The relationship between the PRC and the Philippines has been improving significantly since Duterte became president. This new relationship is built at the expanse of the US-Philippine relations. The US still calls the Philippines a close ally and maintains defence treaties with the country. Besides recent negative diplomatic trends, the Philippines confirmed that the USA are allowed to continue using military bases in the country. The PRC can only undermine this alliance by approaching the Philippines in a more cooperative manner. Indeed, that’s happening through Chinese investment projects as part of the overall Road and Belt initiative. Assessing the relationship between the PRC and Vietnam is complex. Both countries fought each other in the Sino-Vietnamese war. The majority of incidents in the SCS are Sino-Vietnamese confrontations. Also, the government in Hanoi is recently trying to improve its relationship with the USA. On the other hand, this new relationship isn’t strong enough yet to impose a real strategic threat to the PRC. For instance, it seems unlikely that Vietnam would adhere to US sanctions imposed on Russia who is an important trading partner for the country. Furthermore, Vietnam’s economic stability depends on exports/imports to the PRC. As a result, despite minor incidents in the SCS, it seems unlikely that Vietnam and the PRC would provoke major confrontations. Finally, there is a possibility for a Sino-US confrontation. Indeed, the US Navy reports that PRC vessels shadowed US Navy ships in the past and that, despite some critical events, the Navy command will maintain its strategy to conduct FONOPS close to Chinese artificial islands in the SCS. However, both countries are too intertwined to risk an outbreak of a major conflict between them. Trump’s current policy of punitive tariffs against the PRC does not significantly decrease the importance of this trade relation. Ramming and harassing might increase in Sino-US encounters, though, both states should be very hesitant to inflict serious damage on each other or even cause the death of an opponent’s military personnel.  To conclude, the SCS represents one of the major political arenas in this and (at least) the following decade. Littoral states as well as powers with global reach try to influence the development in their favour. Such political dynamics can cause confusion and might lead to an escalation which spirals out of control. However, the regional economic ties, the actual trends and the low interest of involved parties to seriously escalate the conflict decreases the likelihood for lethal confrontations within the SCS. EAST CHINA SEA (ECS) 
The epicentre of the conflict of interest between the PRC and Japan lies on the territorial affiliation of the Diaoyu/Senkaku Islands (comprising uninhabited islands and maritime features) in the ECS. Both states claim that they are the legitimate owner of these islands. There has been a territorial dispute since 1895 when Japan established its sovereignty over the islands after defeating the Chinese Qing Empire. After the Japanese defeat in the WW2 the islands were property of individuals, but still remained within the Japanese jurisdiction as a part of the state. The PRC officially stated its claim in the 1970s based on historical rights derived from the Qing empire. Latest tensions stem from events in 2012 when Japan’s government bought 3 islands within the archipelago. The Diaoyu/Senkaku islands’ value derives from its strategic position next to one of the most important international shipping routes, lush fish stocks and energy resources reservoirs.  The last incident was a clash between Chinese fishermen and the Japanese coast guard near the Diaoyu/Senkaku islands in 2010. Zack Cooper, analyst from the Asia Maritime Transparency Initiative (CSIS), elaborates why new incidents are more likely to happen in the future by presenting scenarios which would lead to higher tensions or even a military escalation. He argues that clashes are more likely to happen due to ongoing disputes over fishing rights, the increasing number of PRC or Taiwanese vessels in the disputed waters, the rise of activities concerning the oil and gas exploitation, an aggressive implementation of air rights above disputed areas and potential collisions through the increased use of unmanned vehicles. These are fictious scenarios which might happen but don’t have to take place. As a result, it seems very unlikely that a lethal confrontation will take place until the end of this year as this would be an extraordinarily fast escalating scenario itself.   Japan: 44‘496 (1,0%) | 44‘552 (1,0%)| 44’836 (1,0%) | 45’351 (0,9%) | 45’362 (0,9%)
PRC: 137’890 (1,9%)| 161’441 (1,8%)| 191’627 (1,9%)| 215’718 (1,9%)| 239’223 (1,9%) Japan’s military expenditure remains (roughly) the same in total and relative terms. The Japanese spending for their coast guard remained (almost) the same in relative terms but increased in the actual tonnage. Nonetheless, these numbers don’t indicate a Japanese militarization.   The diplomatic relationship between the PRC and Japan are heavily influenced through the Japanese invasion of China during the second world war. Up to this day, the PRC lacks trust in Japan’s regional ambitions. Chinese politicians also accuse Japan of a lack of humility with regards to committed atrocities by Japanese soldiers. On the opposite side Japan mistrusts the PRC’s regional goals as it critically assesses the Chinese efforts to increase their military capabilities, as well as its ambitious economic development projects (One Belt One Road initiative), as a wave of Chinese expansionism. However, the PRC and Japan maintain vital economic ties between them which decreases the probability for a deliberate escalation. The implemented “communication mechanism” will further help to avoid serious confrontations and will boost regional collaboration among all involved parties.  To conclude, this forecast assesses a very low probability that there will be a lethal confrontation in the SCS or ECS. Indeed, there are clashes from time to time and these contain the potential to spiral out of control. However, the overall political and economical dynamics don’t indicate a drastic increase of tensions in these regions as the amount of confrontations decline while the military budgets remain stable (or in the case of the PRC: it raises within “reasonable” levels). This might change in the following years if the PRC and littoral states maintain their occupation strategy while the international community remains absent. The Council on Foreign Relations back this assessment by determining the conflict potential as “Unchanging” for both areas. Also, the average of the crowd forecast tends towards a low percentile.  Note: A future update will examine US reports regarding their FONOPS in the SCS and the ECS. Obviously, the security environment in the South and East China Sea is very tense. It is even believed to be potentially the most dangerous point of conflict in Asia. Regardless, I believe that a lethal confrontation in the South or East China Sea between the military forces, militia, or law enforcement personnel of China and another country has a very low likelihood to occur before 1 January 2020. 

	South China sea has been a reason of dispute between several countries, such as China, Taiwan, the Philippines, Vietnam, Malaysia and Brunei. While other countries claim several islands, reefs, rocks or other somewhat minor parts of the sea, the people’s Republic of China (RPC) and the Republic of China (known as Taiwan) are the ones that argue that almost whole part of the South China sea is theirs. The worth of the global trade passing through the sea every year has been estimated to be 5 trillion US dollars, making it very attractive for all the countries involved.  	China’s been quite harsh while demanding its part in the South China Sea. Back in 2009 they even issued “dashed line” map. Beijing is basically occupying and building on disputed parts of the South China sea. As described by some, “its activities are the most widespread and destabilizing”. The major drivers for China to seek the territories of the sea are: first, the sea is rich in oil, giving China economic benefits to become energy exporter; second, China sees the sea as its “front door” and tries to make it as secure as possible; and third, the South China sea has been perceived as a matter of nationalism and identity within Chinese people. These three reasons also make it very complicated to negotiate on the matters of the dispute with China.  	China is trying to become a “maritime power” and there have been 70 significant incidents in the South China sea since 2010. According to statistics, at least one Chinese maritime law enforcement was involved in 73% of the incidents. The peak of incidents was in 2015-2016, after that the number of incidents was reduced and we might expect the numbers to remain the same, as it demonstrates that there’s a low likelihood that there will be any military, militia or law enforcement personnel in the sea before 1 January 2020. Besides, since from 2010 in the lethal confrontation there weren’t any of those institutions involved.   	The East China Sea has been a reason of disputes between the People’s Republic of China, Japan and South Korea, mainly on the extent of the exclusive economic zones. There have been number of incidents. For example, one occurred in 2010 between Japan and China resulting in the arrest of the Chinese fishing captain and causing a diplomatic row between the parties. Another major incident took place in 2016. Around 300 fishing vessels and 16 CCG vessels entered the area of the sea. Japan didn’t expect this and lodged over 30 protests with the Chinese government. According to the Japanese officials, Chinese vessels constantly enter the territorial sea and contiguous zones using armed forces. However, the countries involved have been negotiating on peaceful solutions, since an armed conflict in the sea will be devastating for everyone. 	I believe that there are higher chances that something above-mentioned can occur in the South China sea, but I also assume that the current trend will continue and there won’t be a lethal confrontation between the military forces, militia or law enforcement personnel of China and other country before January 1st of 2020. However, the forecast is reduced by only 10% given that across March and April China 'increased its military activity in the South China Sea by conducting a series of naval maneuvers and exercises' (Global Conflict Tracker 2019). This illustrates a preparedness by China that cannot be ignored. At the same time, this year the US has also increased its military activity in the area, including its freedom of navigation operations (FONOPs).  With the US being the main contender for casualty-causing conflict at the moment, it seems highly unlikely either state will the be the first to take the conflict beyond the symbolic level. U.S. reluctance to prompt escalation may be rooted in increasing Chinese-Russian alliances (an alliance that would seriously threaten U.S. security); and Chinese reluctance to prompt escalation may be rooted in the threat of the U.S. military prowess and their wide-spanning Western backing. In sum: the forecast stands at 20% to account for factors or preparedness and hesitation (where hesitation to escalate it determined to far outweigh preparedness to conduct military warfare on either side).

While China is the main perpetrator of maritime sea incidents in both the South and East China Sea. The available data suggests that a lethal confrontation between China and another country would be unlikely. Since 2010, there have been 63 maritime incidents in the South China sea, in 54 of these China was an actor, yet China was not a actor in the 3 three incidents since 2010 that left a total of 4 fisherman dead (https://chinapower.csis.org/maritime-forces-destabilizing-asia/). This is significant for two reasons. First, the three incidents that have occurred in the South China Sea resulting in death wouldn't count as a lethal confrontation because there were no military, militia or law enforcement deaths. Secondly, incidents involving China seem to be handled more professionally as no deaths have been reported. This is not to say that China doesn't engage in aggressive behavior as they certainly have fired upon ship and rammed them, but rather that other maritime sea actors  tend to refrain from engaging in aggressive actions against China. Thereby, decreasing the probability of a lethal confrontation. Another important point is that there has been a deescalation in the past years. Incidents reached their peak in 2015 and 2016 reaching high teens, but in 2017 and 2018 dropped back down to normal levels of low single digits (https://chinapower.csis.org/maritime-forces-destabilizing-asia/). If this trend continues there is a very low likelihood of lethal confrontation in the South China Sea.  The East China Sea is a bit trickier. There is less data available on incidents, but largely speaking incidents are rarer. That said the main actors are China, Japan and sometime Taiwan.  These actors easily have the capabilities to compete with each other, thereby not diffusing a situation and instead escalating it to the point where they use these capabilities, resulting in a lethal confrontation.  However, it is within all parties involved interests to deescalate conflicts, because the fallout from them would be devastating for everyone. Since 2018 efforts have been made to cooperate more in the East China Sea. For instance China and Japan announced a new crisis hotline in June of 2018 in order to improve communication and avoid incidents (https://www.cfr.org/interactive/global-conflict-tracker/conflict/tensions-east-china-sea).  In sum, the South China Sea has a greater chance of incidents occurring, but because of China's superiority  a lower chance of one of these incidents being a lethal confrontation and the current trend is a deescalation of conflict. That said it only takes one Chinese vessel to act aggressively towards a Coast Guard vessel of another country, potentially causing a fatality. For this reason I give the likelihood of this happening a 5% chance by January 1st, 2020. Now in the East China Sea there is a lower likelihood of incidents, but a higher likelihood of a lethal confrontation because of more equal capabilities of the actors. This means that the actors are less likely to back down in an incident and have the option to use not only lethal force, but more deadly lethal force. While tensions do remain high in this area there are signifiers that indicate possible deescalation, moreover it is all parties interests to keep lethal confrontations from happening as there is a high potential of their being significant consequences. Therefore, it is possible, but remains unlikely that a lethal confrontation will occur, therefore, I grant the likelihood to be 5% in the East China Sea.

Base rate for the forecast at hand is the history of lethal clashes between China and other states in the Chinese sea since the end of World War II. 4 lethal clashes have been occurred: 1974; 1988; 2001 and 2005. So the likelihood of another lethal clash occurring in 2019 could be estimated as of about 5% - with no lethal clash so far having occurred in the East China sea (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_South_China_Sea_dispute#cite_note-64). Based upon the former mentioned incidents 3 actors can be detected, with relevance for the question at hand: Vietnam, China and the US. Additionally, Japan plays a crucial role. Noticeably, 3 out of the 4 lethal incidents were between China, on the one hand, and South Vietnam, as well as after the reunification Vietnam, on the other hand. Furthermore, one incident took place with respect to the US (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_South_China_Sea_dispute#cite_note-64). Thus, a look into Chinese-Vietnamese-US current relationships is crucial for an adequate forecast, as well as in a second step, an analysis of Japanese-US-Chinese relationships in order to include the likelihood of a lethal incident materializing in the East China sea, despite the fact that it hasn’t happened yet. By covering the regional states Vietnam and Japan, as well as the great powers China and the US the forecast at hand gives credit to the fact that even though the conflicts started as regional disputes between neighboring states,China’s role as an aspiring great power and the US, on the other hand, aiming to maintain its influence in East Asia, led to the current state of affairs, where the disputes now have expanded to include the elements of great power competition. Interests and perceptions of the neighboring states mix with aspects of strategic competition between the USA and China (https://www.swp-berlin.org/fileadmin/contents/products/studien/2017S03_cbk.pdf).  With regard to the Vietnam-US-China Triangle, it is worth noticing that Vietnam - whenever its sovereignty has been challenged, has reacted extremely consequent. This is particularly true for the South China Sea. This goes hand in hand with an overwhelmingly negative perception within Vietnamese population towards China and the threat it poses to Vietnamese sovereignty (http://time.com/5440653/vietnam-us-china-balance/), as well as a strategic partnership with the US to counter Chinese interests in that region. However, China remains the most important trade partner of Vietnam and both regimes share close ideological backgrounds. Furthermore, Communist Party General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong who assumed the role of President on October 23, 2018, has close ties with communist leaders in China. While China’s “regional influence has grown as its $1 trillion Belt and Road Initiative has helped fund infra-structure projects in countries across Asia and beyond. Washington’s influence on the region, by contrast, has waned under President Donald Trump, especially after he withdrew the U.S. from the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) intended to reduce regional reliance on Beijing.” (http://time.com/5440653/vietnam-us-china-balance/). To sum up, the forecast at hand does not expect Vietnam to provoke an escalation in the South China sea due close economic and ideological ties with China. However, in case of a Chinese aggression, Vietnam is expected to react harshly, with a high likelihood of escalation and causalities.  Thus, the likelihood of a lethal incident realizing in the South China sea in 2019, depends heavily on the Chinese course of action, which in turn depends on the strategic rivalry with the US. The context of great power competition, is based upon the assumption that for China the diplomatic, economic and military efforts and costs of the disputes outstrip the possible gains by far (https://www.swp-berlin.org/fileadmin/contents/products/studien/2017S03_cbk.pdf). Thus, one can argue it is about China’s great power aspirations and national self-understanding, which clashes heavily with the US’s aspirations to defy corresponding actions, further prioritized and escalated by the Trump administration. Based upon this rivalry a further armament in the South Chinese Sea is expected, which lead to an increased likelihood of lethal incidents, caused by both planned and wanted actions, as well as by accidents like the lethal 2001 incident.  In the East China Sea, it is mainly Japanese and Chinese armed forces or coastguards that are involved. So far, a symbolic equilibrium had settled there. Although the US plays an important role as Japan's protective power in this conflict, unlike in the South China Sea, it has so far hardly appeared as a direct military actor. The actual territorial conflict does not yet seem to be superimposed by direct competition from major powers, and the opponents China and Japan have so far had roughly the same potential to pursue military symbolic policies. However, this equilibrium is unlikely to last long, since Japan cannot keep up with China's enormous maritime armament in the long run, although it is also making considerable efforts to arm itself. This in turn suggests that the US will sooner or later intervene in Japan's symbolic test of strength in the East China Sea, particularly because of the former elaborated aspirations of the US with regard to China (https://www.swp-berlin.org/fileadmin/contents/products/studien/2017S03_cbk.pdf). Based upon former analysis, the forecast at hand comes to the conclusion that the likelihood of lethal incidents realizing in the South or East China Sea has to be estimated higher than the initial 5% base rate, particularly due to worsening relationships between China, on the one hand, and the US, as well as Japan, respectively, on the other hand. Thus, the forecast at hand adds a 10% likelihood for an incident in the South China sea, as well as a 5% likelihood of an incident in the East China sea on the 5% base rate, concluding with a 20% likelihood for a lethal clash to materialize in 2019.

The situation in the South/East China Sea is undoubtedly very tense. “China has rapidly modernized and expanded its navy, which last year became the world’s largest, with more warships and submarines than the United States” (Quartz 2018). China’s territorial ambition in the region has the merit to be clear as Beijing shows great interest in controlling the zone and to expand its influence.  The incidents in the South and East China sea are very common and the implication of China is as follows:
2018: 2/2 
2017: 3/6 
2016: 12/15
2015: 8/10
2014: 7/7
2013: 3/4 
2012: 3/3 
2011: 6/6
2010: 2/2 
Hence, China is involved in almost 1/2 incidents. However, the deaths are particularly unusual and did not involve Beijing so far, or at least since 2010. Since 2010, there were 3 lethal confrontations: 2014: Philippines/Taiwan; 2015: Thailand/Vietnam; 2017: Philippines/Vietnam.  There is no doubt that Beijing is perpetually attempting to reinforce its position and capacities in the geopolitical hotspot. As an illustration of power in the area, the archipelago of Spratleys gathers the largest number of artificializations and has become a logistic extension for China in the sea. The installation of administration and economic activities on the archipelago has added a civilian presence to the military settlement. The government has made it clear that it is willing to do anything to sit down its interests. If there is currently no lethal incident involving China, the confrontations remain very agressive.   Nevertheless, on the basis of the incidents listed -- and taking into account the absence of lethal confrontation between a Chinese actor and another country since 2010 -- I give a very low probability for a lethal confrontation in the South or East China Sea before January 1st 2020. If the aggressiveness of this conflict is not lacking, I believe that China is more acting on deterrence. The “little blue men” is one good illustration of this deterrence, in my opinion. By using irregular maritime forces through fishermen, Beijing settles its predominant presence while sowing confusion and frustration among opponents. China’s claims in the South China Sea are constant since the end of WW2. In particular, Beijing claims sovereignty over the Parcels and Spratyls islands in the South China Sea and Senkaku-Diaoyu in the East China Sea. Japan, Vietnam and the United States dispute these claims and form an alliance. Last but not least, there is China’s claim over Taiwan, a country military protected and assisted by the US which China as never considered as independent (but instead as its own territory). Of course, what has always held China back from moving from words to deeds is the military superpower of the US.  However, since “the great leap forward” initiated by Mao Tse-tung, China has been tremendously growing, both economically and militarily, getting closer and closer to America’s supremacy. Therefore, as a realist would strongly argue, it is just a matter of time before these 2 giants will clash against each other. In this sense, South and East China Sea unsolved claims might offer the perfect justification. These concerns are shared by the Pentagon. In fact, Pentagon's intelligence agency has recently published its first public report assessing the military power of China as a country that the United States increasingly views as a threat to its interests. Finally, China slowing economy and growing internal discontent might lead the communist government to embrace what in International Relations is known as a “rally around the flag strategy”, meaning the strategy to focus the internal opinion on an external threat in order to increase support. Little wonder therefore that recently Beijing has started showing its muscles. As evidence of that, president Xi Jinping has recently ordered the Southern Theatre Command, responsible for monitoring the South China Sea and Taiwan, to boost its military capabilities to prepare for a possible conflict, according to a Hong Kong newspaper. However, given these considerations, I doubt that a lethal conformation, although very likely in the long run, will happen from now to 1 January 2020. It is undeniable that China is exponentially increasing its military presence, but at the moment it looks just a deterrence strategy, albeit particularly aggressive. Furthermore, China’s is currently engaged in many delicate diplomacy actions, the “new Silk Road” and China belt above all. With such ambitious trade projects, it would be counterproductive for China to attract attention to long-lasting territorial deputies. Especially now that, except for Italy (which just signed a trade memorandum with China), the European Union is raising concern regarding Chinese way to conduct business. Therefore, a sudden attack of Chinese army would give the perfect pretext to the West to blame China and adopt protectionist measures (which with both the support of the US and EU would seriously damage Chinese interests). Hence, I assess a very low likelihood of a military confrontation between China and its neighbors in the next year.  Having said that, the question does not refer to a large-scale confrontation. Cornerwise, just “a lethal confrontation” from now to 1 January 2020 would be enough to validate this question. This makes the likelihood less unlikely. With such a military presence in the China sea, a lethal confrontation cannot be completely excluded. It could also happen simply by error with following apologizes and no consequences, but the outcome of this forecast would still be “yes”.  Nevertheless, since 2010, despite many accidents and tensions, there have been no victims.  Concluding, acknowledging that a single lethal confrontation could happen at any time but that at the same time the likelihood of this happening is low, I assess a 20% chance of such an outcome. In the last decade China has shown its intention in conquering maritime domination (no more only territorial lands like Tibet, Xinjiang or the controversial island of Taiwan). It’s since the middle of 20th century that the country pushes for the control of the South/East Chinese Sea, in particular claming the islands Paracels, Spratylas, Scarborough Reef, Macclesfield Bank, Senkaku and Diaoyu islands.
The area is subject of controversies of different countries claiming territories, but China is surely the most determinate and aggressive one. In the past China has already engaging periods of higher or lower tensions, and since 2010 that her presence has become more aggressive. China perpetrates attacks or debatable manoeuvres, provoking foreigner ships, or invading the territorial waters of other countries. Also, China is militarizing the area, building more and more military bases on artificial bases. The reasons of its interest are the presence of oil fields in the China meridional sea, plus the fact that it’s an area extremely proliferous of trade routes. I assess the probability of a lethal confrontation to 15% because:
- We should remember the project for which China is building infrastructure in Asia, Africa and Europe, investing an impressive flow of money: the construction of the BRI (which project is both by sea and by land). Establishing its power on the southern Chinese sea would ensure its control of the area when the project will be ready to use.
These investments that China is making in trade would be damaged in case of a lethal confrontation in the area, creating confusion and the reactions from local countries. So, China has no interest in overpassing the limit of the “simply” demonstration of power.
- From the other side of the front, the ASEAN countries are not in the position of respond too heavily to China attacks, because, even if some of them are strong economic powers and have powerful alliances as the US, they have different interests and won’t be able to compete with the power and the military superiority of China. 
- China knows that Washington has interests in the Chinese sea, wants to contrast the rise of China and in the past has defended the local countries against Chinese efforts in dominating the region (also signing agreement with countries like Japan, or the implementing project of coordinated military exercise that US is currently practicing with Philippines). Again, to have prosperity in trades China has better keep the environment around her controlled (inspiring to Monroe doctrine in the US maybe?) and not surround itself with enemies.
- The accidents that occur from 2010 until 2018 involving in China are a lot (2 in 2010, 6 in 2011, 3 in 2012, 3 in 2013, 7 in 2014, 8 in 2015, 11 in 2016, 3 in 2017, 2 in 2018, but in none case these accidents, apparently, cause any victims.  Again, I assume that even if China is being aggressive, it is trying to obtain the most advantages from its position, even violating the International Law of the Sea, testing and deteriorating the geopolitical balances, but without overcoming the threshold of the military offended; at least not in this year.
- China is using the “little blue men” strategy (soldiers masked as fishermen but equipped with military supplies). To me, this might be interpreted as the effort of not challenging actively the local countries.
- On the other side, China is also implementing a Code of Conduct with the ASEAN countries since 2017, is practicing some joint exercises with ASEAN countries (June 2018), and is also financing countries as Philippine and Vietnam to develop their infrastructure. Therefore, I think China is somehow practicing a dual strategy: on one side, investing in the ASEAN countries and signing bilateral agreement to create an economic dependency, on the other side, showing its military superiority. However, I asset a probability of the 15% for the presence of a military attack because, according to the statistics, the amount of accidents has increased in the last years. Also, China has never really tried to reach a peaceful balance with those countries: it didn’t accept to show up in front of International Court, doesn’t recognise the ASEAN countries as a unified trade partner and prefer to establish only bilateral agreement with them. Plus, the episode that’s going on in the Philippines (Thitu island surrounded by around 200 Chinese ships) and the interests of US in that area can’t exclude completely an escalation of the crisis. Tensions arising from overlapping claims to the EEZ in the South China Sea (SCS) have been ongoing for decades. Major players include China, Taiwan, Vietnam, Malaysia and the Philippines. These tensions have gained serious traction in more recent years, with China occupying and building up military bases on artificial islands in disputed waters.  This year’s Preventative Priorities Survey, produced by the U.S. Council on Foreign Relations’ Centre for Preventative Action, ranks a conflict in the South China Sea as a Tier 1 priority — indicating an anticipation of conflict by experts on global armed conflict and international disputes (CFR 17 Dec 2018).  Since 2010, there have been 59 incidents in the South China Sea. 84% of which involved at least one vessel from Chinese maritime enforcement. China has been the primary actor in the SCS disputes thus far, and given its tendency (in terms of rates), is set to continue. This statement is supported further by the stance taken by the President of China himself. President Xi  has indicated intentions — or at  least not overtly opposed — to enter into conflict in the SCS. Comments claiming it is necessary to “concentrate preparations for fighting a war,” have been made (Quartz 28 Oct 2018). The Stockholm International Peace Research Institute has shown that between 2005 and 2014 military spending by China and Vietnam has risen by 167 and 170% respectively — illustrating some sort or preparedness by China and a key actor in the dispute, Vietnam. Thus, based on previous trends and Xi’s reception to the idea of an armed conflict, the chance of China engaging in an armed conflict in 2019, resulting in a fatality, is considered reasonable (forecasted at 30%). However, it is considered far more likely that the dispute will remain largely symbolic (through deterrence actions eg.) and China’s more aggressive actions (such as occupying large territories in the disputed waters) will go ‘unchallenged’ in a physical sense of the term. Given China’s sheer size and power, it is unlikely that significantly less powerful actors will be willing to bear arms. And, in consideration of China’s aggressive attitude to the dispute, an armed conflict will most likely develop if China’s sovereignty were seen to be seriously threatened — possibly by key actors taking arms.  But with tensions having been ongoing for such a long period, the trend indicates that sudden escalation to armed conflict resulting in casualties is low, at least in the next 8.5 months.

The confrontations in the China Sea between different protagonists are not rare. There are territorial disputes in this sea for the control of the islands and archipelagos of the Spratleys, Paracels, Pratas, Scarborough Reef and Macclesfield Bank, between the various countries of South-East Asia. In March 1988, the Chinese navy defeats the Vietnamese Navy, killing 64 Vietnamese, for example. In addition, Beijing is aggressive through its actions in the area, including the takeover of the Scarborough Reef in 2012; the dispatch of air and naval patrols in the airspace and territorial waters of the Senkaku / Diaoyu Islands; the establishment of an air defense identification zone over the East China Sea in November 2013.
Therefore, China is pursuing an expansionist policy in the region to ensure its zone of influence. China has rapidly modernized and expanded its navy (paywall), which last year became the world’s largest, with more warships and submarines than the United States (Source : Quartz). In response, the coastal states of Southeast Asia are rearming, which tends to increase the lethal potential of the incidents. However, it becomes difficult to say whether the incidents are related to Chinese military forces or not. Indeed, the recognition and use of ships become unclear because the fishing boats are armed. Like Russia in Crimea and its "Little Green Men", China has been deploying “Little Blue Men” in the maritime domain to harass Beijing’s adversaries in the South China Sea and to press its territorial claims (Source :https://thediplomat.com/2015/11/little-blue-men-doing-chinas-dirty-work-in-the-south-china-sea/). There is therefore a broader inclusion to make to describe Chinese forces, which now includes armed "fishermen". This reinforces the potential for lethal conflict, as militias are less organized and more aggressive than regular forces.
However, we can look at the incident statistics since 2010 to issue a forecast:
2018 = 2 incidents (all including China)
2017 = 6 incidents (3 with China), 1 death between Philippines and Vietnam
2015 = 10 incidents (8 with China), 1 death between Thai and Indonesia
2014 = 7 incidents (all including China) (including a one-and-a-half month standoff with Vietnam)
2013 = 4 incidents (3 with China), 1 death between Philippine and Taiwan
2012 = 3 Incidents (all including China)
2011 = 6 incidents (all including China)
2010 = 2 incident (all including China)
Source: https://chinapower.csis.org/maritime-forces-destabilizing-asia/
Incidents including China are therefore all relatively numerous each year, with at least 2. The shots, ramming, arrests, are relatively common too. However, in 8 years, China has not officially made any victims.
There is therefore a context of tension, but the lethal confrontations with China have not been made for a decade, in a context that analysts say are very tense because of the Chinese expansionist policy, while lethal conflicts were more common before this policy.
The percentage of lethal confrontation between Chinese forces and another state is lower than one might think, but far from impossible because of the inclusion of "Little Blue Mens" and the frequency of incidents.

The Council on Foreign Relations (CFR) warns about the possibility of military escalation in the South Chinese Sea. "While a military confrontation between China and another claimant was not assessed to be highly likely in 2019, the impact on U.S. interests would be significant. Its defense treaty with Manila could draw the United States into a potential China-Philippines clash over valuable energy resources or fishing grounds in disputed waters. Any conflict in the South China Sea would also threaten the security of a region through which trillions of dollars of trade passes through annually, with potentially far-ranging and severe consequences" (https://www.cfr.org/blog/top-conflicts-watch-2019-south-china-sea). The economic and national interests linked to the dispute over this sea are clear, and as such the CFR includes the possibility of conflict among the eleven conflict prevention priorities in 2019 (https://www.cfr.org/report/preventive-priorities-survey-2019). Even if the US strong claims over the area and the already mentioned issues at stake, the recent environment created between China and the Philippines - in a so cooperative sense that the Philippines' President was fiercely criticized - reduce the likelihood of deadly confrontation. All in all, I think the path the confrontation will follow will remain pacific, at least in the medium term. China has proven to be able to pursue its aims without recurring to military options, and the vast international projects on track (the new silk roads etc) could be put in jeopardy by a military escalation deriving from a lethal confrontation in the South or East China Sea. If the event to be forecasted here will happen, it wil be most likely due to an accident - law enforcement operation to remove fishermen from a contested sea area etc - which at sea are surely not negligible, most of all given the military built up in the small islands.Adding also the contested areas in the East Chinese Sea (https://www.cnbc.com/2017/12/20/east-china-sea-could-be-riskier-than-south-china-sea.html), the area in which incidents (more probable) or proper military offensives (which I consider less likely) can take place is definetly huge, and very trafficked (a fair percentage of the world's maritime trade takes place in these seas)

Breaking this down into a couple of parts, first the assumption that such an event occurs in general means (either through intent or not) and second under the assumption that escalations in tensions with any specific country causes such a conflict. General: Consensus here seems to be 5-10 %, I would generally agree with most of the rationale going into this assertion. Only hole I see here is a number of people seem to be interpreting the question as one of the two parties being military personnel, however the parsing of the question requires both to be such. Thus I'll take the low end of this range, 5%. Specific Conflicts...
 - United States: This is highly unlikely (Though perhaps more so nowadays than in the past). The only feasible way I could see this occurring is in the wake of some black-swan level of cascading conflicts as a result of the ongoing trade conflicts. I don't see this adding any tangible contribution to my prediction. (< 0.1%)
 - North Korea: Again highly unlikely, North Korea exists in large part due to the complacency of China & China's interests in the Korean peninsula are better off with a cohesive North Korea. I don't foresee any events that would  disrupt this relationship
 - India or Pakistan: If this conflict were to escalate dramatically (unlikely, but given recent transgressions plausible) then China would be placed in an uncomfortable position. Support Pakistan & risk open conflict with India (Highly unlikely, but again fully plausible) or isolate Pakistan and risk open conflict along China's Belt & Road Initiative. I would consider this very-unlikely overall, but given the recent open conflict this is substantially higher than the previous two considerations. I'll say 2% as of now.
 - Taiwan: Technically Taiwan is considered to be part of the Republic of China, thus I'm assuming this question would include them as such? I'll predict this under this assumption, otherwise this would potentially increase the odds a decent amount (assuming reunification talks go south). The most likely course here in my view would be rebel pro-independence forces in Taiwan rebelling against the seemingly pro-unification government in Taipei.

To start, I HIGHLY doubt that any state would start a confrontation with China. Power lies in perception, not material; and with China holding the #1 spot in terms of GDP (PPP), it is unlikely that any state will want to jump into any military confrontation with China, who has steadily increased its military spending over the last decade. What I'm getting at is that China looks too daunting for any state to be willing to start the fighting, placing this question's burden on China starting the confrontation.  Let's see if China is bold enough to start confrontation:
For example, the Sino-Japanese dispute over the Diaoyu Islands, predating WWII, is a good example to observe Chinese actions in the South/East China Sea. Various treaties and war reparations have left the islands' sovereignty claims to interpretation, but the Chinese have aggressively (but without force) established de facto control over the area through their pursuit of strategic positioning and economic exploitation. What's keeping China from using force, though, is the presence of the United States (due to treaty obligations to Japan after post WWII occupation) in the region. China is a huge potential military power, but the likelihood of China starting the confrontation is tiny. They have a quasi-navy (coastguard) patrolling the S/E Sea protecting their economic interests there, and I doubt that the US would want to harm those interests (mutual benefit), so they'll leave China alone for the time being while using sanctions and the UN to give the CCP a small slap on the wrist. The legal claims brought forth by China to these islands (and the similar southern ones) are far stronger than that of the Japanese, and have held ground when combined with their military/economic presence. I don't think they'll need to use force, or "lethal confrontation" to sustain their efforts in the area, so I'm not going to predict that China to will attack either.  That just leaves me with placing this prediction at 3%. I don't see any state mustering up the courage to attack China, nor do I foresee China pushing any lethal force as their current tactics have already made so much progress; that knocks off a solid 99% of this happening. I'm adding in 2% just because no once can accurately predict if Donald will do something outrageous.

Chinese President Xi has initiated several initiatives under his "China Dream of national rejuvenation” plans, to include the "One Belt One Road" objectives stretching into Africa. The "China Dream' focuses on key factors such as: 
•      Emphasis on maritime and information domains
•	Offensive air operations 
•	Long-distance mobility operations
•	Space/cyber operations
These points coincide with stressing combatant and joint commands within China and evolving to handle short term high intensity conflicts in the Pacific.  The significant sea lane routes (SLRs) already controlled by China are heavily defended with Anti-Access/ Area Denial (A2AD) through complex integrated air defense systems (IADS), which is a heavy deterrent for opposing forces. The U.S., under President Obama began a "Pivot to Asia" policy beginning in 2011, which essential is an attempt to contain Chinese expansion or spheres of influence by building areas of cooperation to reduce risk, while preserving the ability to compete successfully from a position of strength, such as:  
•	Monitoring and adapting to China’s evolving military strategy and encouraging transparency of military modernization
•	Retaining abilities to defend the homeland, deter aggression, protect/ build with our allies/partners, and preserve regional peace, prosperity, and freedom.
However, there always exists a chance of miscalculation and the U.S. should avoid the "Thucydides Trap" (It was the rise of Athens and the fear that this instilled in Sparta that made war inevitable") as from Chinese perspective is that they have the right to become a regional hegemony and practice their version of the U.S.'s Monroe Doctrine. Due to the slight chance of miscalculation, I assess China and U.S./ Allies have a low risk of lethal confrontation before 1 January 2020. Non-U.S. allies would not stand any chance of military confrontation with China.
