While I see a ~95% probability of occurrence in 2030 ±1 year, probability of major/external Chinese conflict in any given year is only ~56.5/(2019-1927.5) = 62% (φ-1). Narrowing down to external conflicts in South|East China Seas we get ~5/91.5 = 5%. Sourcing from: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_wars_involving_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China

According to the Correlates of War dataset, China has been in 26 interstate disputes from 2002 to 2010 (2002 marking the beginning of Hu Jintao's term of power, the Chinese leader before the current leader of China, Xi Jinping). Out of these 26 disputes, none have produced a fatality. Out of these 26 disputes, only 8 resulted in the use of force by one of the disputants (31%). Of these 8 uses of force, none were carried out by China. It appears to me that a fatality is highly unlikely given a strong outside view. I know I'm looking at all of China's disputes, but doing so offers stronger support for my assessment.  Even at the peaks of tension in the South China Sea during the three Taiwan Strait crises, only 2 US troops were killed -- although accidentally. Although Taiwanese and Chinese forces were killed during these crises, I do not anticipate a new Taiwanese crisis any time soon. Taiwan's defenses have improved substantially since then and any serious operation to seize the island would likely falter, according to my understanding of recent assessments. Moreover, the last crisis which occurred in 1995 resulted in no fatalities. If anything, it appears there is a strong mutual effort to avoid escalation despite the serious territorial disagreements in the region.  Nevertheless, this does not discredit the threat of a future escalation of hostilities in the region. China's capabilities in the South China sea are expanding rapidly, eroding the credibility of the US's threat of deterrence. If anything, the likelihood of serious conflict is increasing over time, especially in consideration of China's overall dissatisfaction with the region's status quo. However, the probability of a fatality resulting, in my estimation, is low for the following year. If we extend the scope of the forecasting question to 5 or 10 years, my estimation would rise considerably.

This is an update to my previous forecast. If you assume that the probability of a lethal confrontation is constant from year to year, and we've only seen 1 of these since 1990 (that I'm aware of) then you can model this as binomial distribution. For a given year, there are two outcomes - either 0 lethal confrontations, or 1+ confrontations. The two columns show (A) the probability of getting 1+ confrontations in a given year and (B) the corresponding probability for seeing exactly 1 confrontation over a sample of 28 years.  Column B is highest around 4%, which corresponds to the simple division 1/28=3.57%. This means that (if the above assumption is sound) the most likely reality we're in is in the 1-8% range. So 4% seems to be a suitable base rate, and this can be adjusted up or down depending on 2019's political situation. As I mentioned in my previous forecast, there are 1-2 strong reasons for adjusting up slightly and 1-2 strong reasons for adjusting down slightly. I think the "growing tensions" headline masks actual developments in co-operation; so reasons for adjusting down are stronger. I'm thinking 3% might even be too high; 2% more accurate but I have the fear in me. A		B

South China Sea summary
    • There seems to be a steady trickle of military confrontations. (Most confrontations are military vs non-military – a military vs non-military confrontation is much less likely to result in a death for a member of the military.) Very, very few of these result in military deaths (e.g. 2001 Hainan Island incident). So since, say, 1990, there has been a single death in a military vs military confrontation in the South China Sea. (Please correct me if I am wrong.) 1 death over 28 years. (Edit: Not 18!!)
    • Countries commonly use diplomacy to resolve disputes. (e.g. in 2015, Malaysia sent a diplomatic note about a ship at Luconia Shoals; Indonesia in 2015 announces that it will pursue legal action over Natuna Islands; Philippines said they are willing to share resources).
    • On the other hands, Indonesia uses rattlesnake tactics too; Indonesian president visited Natuna Islands on a warship (https://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-06-23/joko-widodo-visits-south-china-sea-amid-tension-with-china/7539164). But keep in mind the president was on board – so, just from this incident, we can’t conclude that sailing warships past disputed territory is part of Indonesia’s policy.
    • There’s also an argument here (https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/global-opinions/wp/2018/10/09/how-president-trump-is-helping-beijing-win-in-the-south-china-sea/?noredirect=on). I don’t put much stock in opinion posts generally, but this one is by Robert D. Kaplan, who wrote an excellent book on the South China Sea. Kaplan argues that a) China’s policy isn’t about armed conflict, but a steady resource and land creep; and b) the uncertainty caused by Trump’s zigzag approach to policy causes Asian leaders to look to each other. East China Sea summary
    • Since 1990ish, there have only been two disputes that I’m aware of, with 0 total military deaths (2010 Senkaku/Diaoyu Islands; 2012 Chinese reconnaissance aircraft). Seems reasonable to count the confrontations in the South China Sea and those in the East China Sea as similar populations.
    • There’s an excellent report here, although it is from 2013 (https://www.cfr.org/report/sino-japanese-clash-east-china-sea). The report argues that two most likely types of dispute are “Accidental or unintended incident” or “Political miscalculation in demonstrating control”. It says that “Deliberate action to take islands” is highly unlikely.
    • An accidental or unintended incident is far more likely to involve civilians than two militaries. A political miscalculation is less clear. Other factors (a.k.a. The Other Hand)
    • The military spending of China has increased almost exponentially since the late 1990’s. This could mean that a military conflict is more likely. But this hypothesis would mean that there is more military confrontations (even those not involving deaths) in the S/E China Seas since the 1990’s. There seems to have been a hot-spot of confrontations in 2014-16; but the rate here isn’t much higher than the base rate. It’s certainly not exponentially increasing. This means that it isn’t hands-down obvious that more military spending means more chance of a military conflict in the Seas.
    • Then there’s the uncertainty factor – as the world transitions from unipolar to multipolar, uncertainty increases. (Another force behind this is Trump’s less coherent foreign policy.) But more uncertainty in an estimate doesn’t mean that the base rate should increase; and, as outlined above, I also think that the transition from unipolarity to multipolarity makes Asian countries more likely to work with China rather than try to engage in conflict. Taken together
    • The one death since the 1990’s means roughly a baseline of 3.7% deaths per year. (Edit: Not 5% as I mistakenly posted)
    • The rate for East China Sea is probably lower – there are fewer players, and Japan has disciplined rules about how its armed forces respond in situations. This would draw the baseline down.
    • Clearly, the distribution is extremely skewed – 0 deaths is most likely by a country mile; 1 death is far less likely; 2 deaths is far less likely than that; and so on. So, we have to imagine, if we draw a number at random from this distribution, what’s the chance that we’ll hit a number above 0? My gut feeling is that the ~5% from above (roughly 1 deaths every 20 years) seems about right. 
    • I’m going to go with the 5%. I will change my mind if:
        ◦ I discover other military deaths in the region since ~1990.
        ◦ There are any relevant news stories – I will monitor, but I’m not sure what signs would give an indication of an impending military death that wouldn’t have already caused a death by the time it makes the news.

Thucydides Trap suggests a 75% probability of war when a rising power challenges an incumbent. Although, the question is not specifically about war, a war would be a resounding "yes" so I'll use that as my base. When more recent instances of such a paradigm are examine (20th and 21st Century) the probability falls to 60% (albeit with only a sample size of 5 - WWI, WWII, Cold War, and German dominance in the Eurozone). Graham Allison's analyses, however, stretch long time horizons, so the next calendar year presents a vexing challenge. I'm setting my base at 35% given prior probabilities based on similar geopolitical events, heightened tensions with Southeast Asia countries, and China's recent use of a maritime militia in recent months. These three factors would imply a higher probability over the long term, but over a year I think they are less likely to result in a death. I also think there is increased focus from both the US and China on trade issues now, so there may be further procautions taken to protect those negotiations.
